Project Description  To  support  the  Government’s  commitment  to  restructure  and 
reform  commercial  banking  in  the  Lao  PDR,  this  Project  will 
introduce sound commercial banking governance structures by 
engaging resident international banking advisors (IBAs) for state-
owned commercial banks (SOCBs). The IBAs will guide the new 
boards and management through a major program of operational 
restructuring,  focusing  on  improved  governance  policies, 
procedures for resolving nonperforming loans (NPLs), and cost 
reduction.  An  information technology (IT) upgrade will support 
these new governance structures by enabling improved financial 
reporting to management, the shareholder, and the supervisory 
authority through more efficient and reliable processing of, and 
reporting on, transactions throughout the nationwide systems. 
   
Rationale  The Government is embarking on a broad reform program aimed 
at macrostability, improved financial management throughout the 
economy,  and  strengthened  private  sector  orientation.  The 
Government’s program is supported by a number of instruments 
including an International Monetary Fund (IMF) poverty reduction 
and growth facility (PRGF), a World Bank financial management 
adjustment credit (FMAC) and capacity-building credit. In addition, 
a Banking Sector Reform Program Loan has been proposed for 
consideration by the Board of Directors of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in November 2002. The goal of all intensive efforts is 
to reform the SOCBs. 
 
  The  Government  has  requested  technical  assistance  (TA)  to 
compensate  for  and  strengthen  the  limited  capacity  of  SOCB 
management and staff to apply and enforce good commercial 
practice and behavior.  The TA loan is an integral part of the 
banking  sector  reform  effort  in  that  it  seeks  to  implement 
principles  of  good  governance  throughout  SOCB  operations. 
Under the TA  loan, the consultants will support banking sector 
reform  by  introducing  sound  commercial  banking  policies  and 
procedures, particularly in relation to the credit approval process 
and  NPL  collection.  On-the-job  experience  coupled  with 
simultaneous formal and informal training by the IBAs will sustain 
the impact of the restructuring program. IT upgrades and training 
will  support  better  control  and  more  efficient  operations  and 
facilitate a well-implemented restructuring effort.

iii 
Objectives and Scope  The TA will foster improvements in governance of the SOCBs and 
in  their  financial  performance  by  introducing  modern  banking 
policies and procedures. This objective will be achieved by (i) 
resolving NPLs through  a case-by-case focus on cash recovery 
and legal action; (ii) ensuring that new flows of credit are secured 
by cash flows; (iii) introducing a client-and-business orientation in 
banking relationships, particularly in assisting small and medium 
enterprises  (SMEs)  to  present  bankable  projects;  and  (iv) 
reducing costs through better economies of scale. 
   
Cost Estimates  The total cost of the project is $4.83 million equivalent, comprising 
foreign exchange costs of $3.51 million and local currency costs 
of $1.32 million equivalent. 
   
Financing Plan  The  proposed  financing  is  for  an  ADB  TA  loan  of  $4  million 
equivalent, including $0.49 million equivalent of the local currency 
cost. The Government will finance a minimum of $0.83 million 
equivalent of local currency costs.

million from ADB's Special Funds resources, with a maturity of 32 
years including a grace period of 8 years, and an interest charge

thereafter. The Borrower will be the Lao PDR.

Consulting Services  Consultants  will  provide  240  person-months  of  consulting 
services: 108 person-months for international consultants and 132 
person-months  for  domestic  consultants.  The  international 
consultants  will  have  expertise  in  bank  management  and

resolution.  The  international  consultants  will  be  four  resident

Project Benefits and  The principal benefit will be greater transparency, certainty, and 
Beneficiaries  predictability  in  commercial  bank  transactions,  particularly  the 
initiation  of  loans  and  the  enforcement  of  loan  and  security 
obligations.  The  changes  will  foster  a  better  environment  for 
commercial  transactions  and  will  allow  the  banks  to  attract  a 
stronger  set  of  borrowers.  A  second  benefit  is  support  for 
macroeconomic stability and poverty reduction by reducing the 
risk  of  banking  sector  instability.  The  lower  risk  premium  of 
lending  rates  will  allow  a  greater  range  of  borrowers  to  gain 
access  to  loan  financing.  Moreover,  reduced  losses  in  SOCB 
capital  will  enable  the  Government  to  reorient  its  expenditure 
framework  toward  higher  priority  social  expenditures.  Another 
important  long-term  benefit  will  be  the  capacity  for  future 
development  of  the  commercial  system  built  into  the  SOCB 
management and staff. The project beneficiaries will include the 
SOCB management and staff, their potential clients, and the wider 
range of the population, including the poor, who will benefit from 
greater stability and economic growth. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The  first  risk  is  the  potential  reemergence  of  macroeconomic 
instability, which would undermine the banking sector reform. This 
macroeconomic  risk  will  be  minimized  through  the  tightly 
monitored fiscal and monetary framework under the IMF’s PRGF, 
and the budget and state-owned enterprise reforms supported by 
the World Bank’s FMAC.

v 
  Second, resistance from defaulting borrowers and other former 
beneficiaries of noncommercial banking activity, particularly in the 
provinces, could erode the political will to sustain the medium-
term reform program. This risk is being mitigated by a program 
initiated more than a year ago in which the Government achieved 
a sense of ownership and facilitated strong coordination among 
the  international  financial  institutions  (IFIs)  in  dialogue  and 
instruments.  This  effort  will  continually  strengthen  throughout 
program implementation. 
 
  The  third  risk  is  that  restructuring  the  SOCBs  may  result  in 
redundancies and this could lead to resentment and grassroots 
resistance. Consultation and awareness building have begun and 
will  continue  throughout  implementation.  The  Government,  in 
consultation with the stakeholders and as agreed upon with ADB, 
has also committed that a mitigation plan will be an integral part of 
the  restructuring  program  should  the  program  have  adverse 
effects on vulnerable SOCB staff.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
technical assistance (TA) loan to  the Lao People's Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the 
Banking Sector Reform Project. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
2.  Following high inflation and currency depreciation in 1998/99, the Government has been 
successful in stabilizing the economy. In April 2001, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) 
approved a three-year arrangement under a poverty reduction and growth facility (PRGF). 
During the first year of the PRGF, inflation remained at around 7% and the economy expanded 
at 5.2%. However, stability is fragile and financial sector restructuring and reforms of state-
owned enterprises are needed to ensure that problems in the banking sector do not contribute 
to macroeconomic instability. 
 
3.  The financial sector in the Lao PDR needs to become considerably deeper through 
improved intermediation and outreach to promote the higher growth required for sustained 
poverty reduction. Currently the sector is dominated by three state-owned commercial banks 
(SOCBs) which collectively account for about 70% of the total assets of the banking system.1 
Branches  of  several  foreign  banks  operate  in  Vientiane,  but  deficiencies  in  the  banking 
environment, particularly the legal and judicial framework in which they operate, and limitations 
on their activities have so far limited their contribution to the domestic economy.  
 
4.  In recent years nonperforming loans (NPLs) have risen significantly and other assets of 
questionable quality have shown worrisome growth. This performance reflects factors external 
to  the  banks,  such  as  the  hangover  from  the  macroeconomic  instability  prior  to  2000, 
deficiencies in the judicial and security system, and borrowers with limited capacity to present 
bankable projects. But there are also fundamental institutional weaknesses, including limited 
human  resource  capacity,  inadequate  information  technology  (IT),  overstaffing,  inadequate 
attention to prudent risk management, and poorly functioning governance structures (e.g., 
boards, committees, policies and procedures). As a result, losses in the SOCB sector totaled 
around $27 million in 1998-2001.  
 
5.  The Government requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide financial and 
technical  support  for  its  program  to  address  the  policy  environment  for,  and  institutional 
weaknesses in, the banking and financial sector. A project preparatory technical assistance 
(PPTA) (i) conducted an operational and financial diagnosis of the SOCBs; (ii) gave additional 
information on SOCB classification and reporting of the credit portfolio; (iii) prepared operational 
and financial restructuring plans for the SOCBs, with special emphasis on strengthening credit 
culture through case-by-case NPL resolution; and (iv) proposed a legal and judicial framework 
to support good banking. The PPTA was completed in June, 2002 and the Government has 
prepared a program aimed at fostering efficient intermediation of depositor resources and 
ensuring a sound banking sector. 
 
6.  The TA loan is a key instrument supporting Government’s banking reform program. In 
addition, a proposed banking sector reform program loan has been prepared for consideration 
by the Board. The Government’s program will foster efficient financial intermediation through the

creation  of  a  sound  banking  sector  capable  of  supporting  private-sector-led  growth  and 
extending  outreach  to  rural  areas.  The  program  would  involve  (i)  introducing  commercial 
principles  in  SOCB  operations;  (ii)  adopting  improved  internal  incentives  and  governance 
structures in the SOCBs; (iii) setting up a legal judicial and prudential regulation system that 
brings failed borrowers, strategic defaulters, and unsound banks to account; (iv) creating a 
range of institutional models and methodologies for extending financial services; and (v) giving 
creditworthy private sector firms a better access to commercial finance. 
 
7.  Under the program, the Government will reduce the number of SOCBs from three to two, 
and modern governance policies and procedures will be introduced to the principal risk areas of 
the  banks:  credit  approvals,  asset/liability  management,  and  internal  audit.  Operational 
restructuring will also involve downgrading or disposing of unprofitable branches accompanied 
by appropriate deployment of the best fixed assets and staff, with particular emphasis on top 
and middle management.  
 
8.  The SOCB restructuring program will require complex skills and expertise not readily 
available in the Lao PDR. The Government requested a TA loan to support 3 years of work of 
international banking advisors (IBAs) and an IT program to assist SOCBs’ boards of directors 
and management teams achieve their objectives. The TA loan forms an integral part of the 
reform program by ensuring three key objectives are achieved: (i) implementation of the recently 
reiterated commercial mandate of the SOCBs, (ii) strengthened credit discipline in banks and 
borrowers through a case-by-case approach to NPL resolution, and (iii) a banking sector that is 
more responsive to the needs of the private commercial sector. The project framework  is in 
Appendix 1. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Objectives 
9.  The objective of the TA is to foster improvements in the governance of the SOCBs by 
introducing modern banking policies and procedures and reversing the financial performance of 
the SOCBs. The objective will be achieved by (i) resolving NPLs through a case-by-case focus 
on cash recovery and legal action; (ii) ensuring that new flows of credit are secured by cash 
flows; (iii) introducing a client-and-business orientation in banking relationships, for example by 
assisting small and medium enterprises (SMEs) to present bankable projects; and (iv) reducing 
costs through better economies of scale.  
  
B.  Components and Outputs 
10.  The TA loan will finance two resident IBAs in each of the two remaining SOCBs for 3 
years, to build capacity while helping to implement the specific restructuring activities. Detailed 
terms of reference for the advisors are in Appendix 2. To support the implementation of new 
governance policies and procedures, the TA will also finance IT systems that allow more 
accurate reporting to management, the shareholder, and the supervisor, and increase efficiency 
and control in processing transactions, particularly for the nationwide branch network. 
 
1.  Implementation of Operational Restructuring Modules 
11.  The SOCBs will undergo full governance reform as the centerpiece of the operational 
restructuring. The reform will be initiated at the top with the installation of new board chairmen, 
board members, and management teams willing and able to take on the challenge of managing

3 
a restructuring effort while absorbing intensive training required to implement new policies and 
procedures.  
 
12.  The principles, terms and conditions associated with operational restructuring have been 
agreed upon in advance in memoranda of understanding between the owner represented by the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF), the Bank of the Lao PDR (BOL) as regulator, and the SOCB that 
commit all parties to a specified program. Included are measurable targets and goals against 
which SOCB performance will be assessed. The Program will be closely supervised and will be 
updated annually on the basis of current conditions and external audits that (i) report on 
performance indicators, (ii) provide operational audits of key areas, and (iii) provide guidance in 
revising the following year’s program.  
 
13.  The first year of operational restructuring will focus on a comprehensive program to 
introduce, implement, and maintain new governance systems including board and management 
committees. Initially, there will be stringent interim operational policies2 that are to be gradually 
replaced with full board-approved policies under the guidance of the IBAs covering the key 
areas of portfolio management, new credit extension, asset/liability management, and internal 
audit. These more effective operational policies and procedures, supported by better systems, 
IT,  and  reporting  methodology  will  be  implemented  throughout  the  SOCBs,  with  special 
emphasis on branches. As a result, decisions will be more transparent, based on commercial 
principles, and accurately recorded. 
 
14.  IBAs will play a critical role in the restructuring activities. Their principal duties will be to 
(i) help banks implement the governance reforms, particularly the board-approved operational 
policies; (ii) oversee improvements in systems and procedures to support these policies; (iii) 
support the comprehensive program of NPL resolution; (iv) assist in downsizing the institutions; 
and (v) continuously monitor key activities, particularly credit origination and NPL resolution.  
 
15.  A key aspect of the Government’s reform program is the emphasis on development of 
human resource capacity within the SOCBs. The IBAs will play a critical role in training and 
coaching the bank staff. The on-the-job training provided by the IBAs will complement and 
reinforce a formal human resource development program involving (i) an effort to match existing 
staff skills to job requirements; and (ii) tailored training programs, including scholarships based 
on the assessed needs in key areas such as accounting, auditing, and IT.3  
 
16.  To strengthen credit discipline for the future, special emphasis will be given to the NPLs. 
A specific plan to address these NPLs has been prepared and will be implemented under the 
guidance of the IBAs. The plan will be based on a case-by-case analysis of each NPL account 
in the portfolio and will include a strategy and detailed implementation procedures, focusing on 
cash collection and court action. Active implementation will be facilitated through performance 
targets  on  banks  and  on  the  judiciary,  which  is  being  strengthened  under  a  part  of  the 
Government’s program.

2.  Upgrade of Information Technology  
17.  Currently all SOCBs in the Lao PDR use the same limited-function back office software 
consisting of a simple general ledger and chart of accounts system. It was developed locally in 
1997, and is limited and outdated.4 The inability to generate accurate and timely management 
and  supervisory  information  hinders  any  ability  to  implement  good  oversight  and  control 
functions. 
 
18.  However, the skill level of IT staff in both BOL and SOCBs is low, and it would be difficult 
to  introduce  a  complex  international  standard  banking  software  system.  The  TA  loan  will 
therefore  assist  the  SOCBs  to  implement  an  intermediate-level  software  package  for  the 
banking system which integrates the front and back offices, provides a low-cost solution and is 
accompanied by an IT training program to ensure a cadre of some 20 well-trained IT staff 
throughout BOL and the SOCBs.5  
 
19.  The scope of the new system will allow SOCBs to 
 
(i)  improve customer service levels for current products and services 
(ii)  expand a range of products and services as the banks’ develop and mature 
(iii)  target services through more efficient operations 
(iv)  improve management information and control processes, and 
(v)  manage cash flows more effectively.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
A.  Benefits and Impacts 
34.  The  principal  benefit  of  the  Project  will  be  greater  transparency,  certainty,  and 
predictability  in  commercial  bank  transactions,  particularly  the  initiation  of  loans  and  the 
enforcement of loan and security obligations. Such a change will foster a better environment for 
commercial transactions and support a stronger set of borrowers.  
 
35.  A  second  benefit  is  support  for  macroeconomic  stability  and  poverty  reduction  by 
strengthening the country’s ability to grow without the attendant risk of banking-sector-instigated 
macroinstability. The lower risk premium of lending rates will give a greater range of borrowers 
access to loan financing. Moreover, reduced SOCB losses will enable the Government to focus 
its expenditures on reducing poverty. The channels for poverty reduction are described in 
Appendix 6.

8   
36.  Another important long-term benefit will be the capacity for future development of the 
commercial system built in to the SOCB management and staff. The project beneficiaries 
include  SOCB  management  and  staff,  their  potential  clients,  and  the  wider  range  of  the 
population, including the poor, who benefit from greater stability and economic growth. 
 
B.  Risks 
37.  The first risk is the potential re-emergence of macroeconomic instability, which would 
undermine the banking sector reform. These macroeconomic risks are being minimized through 
the tightly monitored fiscal and monetary framework under the IMF’s PRGF supported by 
budget and state-owned enterprise reforms supported by the World Bank’s FMAC. 
 
38.  Second,  resistance  from  defaulting  borrowers  and  other  former  beneficiaries  of 
noncommercial banking activity, particularly in the provinces, could erode the political will to 
sustain the medium-term reform program. This risk is being mitigated by a program initiated 
more than a year ago in which the Government achieved a sense of ownership and facilitated 
strong  coordination  among  the  international  financial  institutions  (IFIs)  in  dialogue  and 
instruments. This effort will continually strengthen throughout program implementation. 
 
39.  The third risk is that restructuring the SOCBs may result in redundancies and this could 
lead to resentment and grassroots resistance. Consultation and awareness building have begun 
and  will  continue  throughout  implementation.  The  Government,  in  consultation  with  the 
stakeholders and as agreed upon with ADB, has also committed that a mitigation plan will be an 
integral  part  of  the  restructuring  program  should  the  program  have  adverse  effects  on 
vulnerable SOCB staff.

Poverty in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (PDR), as in most neighboring countries, is concentrated in the 
rural areas. According to the most recently prepared estimates for 1997-98,1 22.1% of the urban population and 
42.5% of the rural population (39.1% of the total population) were poor. Since 83.3% of the population resided in rural 
areas in 1997-98, these estimates imply that 91% of the poor reside in the rural areas. Within the rural areas, the 
poor reside in relatively remote villages, tend to be illiterate or poorly educated, own or have access to limited land 
and other assets, depend largely on subsistence farming both for employment and as a source of income, and live in 
relatively large households with relatively high dependency burdens. 
 
Recently prepared poverty estimates suggest that the poor have benefited from rapid economic growth taking place 
before the economic crises in 1997. Overall, the poor population declined at an annual rate of 3.1% between 1993 
and 1998. However, reductions in poverty have been geographically uneven and urban-rural disparities are widening. 
In particular, those who live outside the monetized economy (i.e., most of the rural poor) have not been able to 
participate in the benefits of economic growth. The banking sector’s contribution to poverty reduction in Lao PDR. 
 
Estimates suggest that in order for the government to reach its poverty reduction goals, economic growth needs to be 
at least 7%.  A sound financial sector – in this case dominated by the state-owned banks – will be an indispensable 
part of this growth rate, as growth is directly linked to a deepening in the financial sector. Further, the soundness of 
banks reflects the general confidence level in the system and can provide the needed price and exchange stability for 
the real economy to expand in a sustainable and broad-based manner.     
 
The banking system is also an important channel through which domestic savings are allocated to support the good 
projects in the private sector, particularly small and medium-size enterprises (SMEs). Currently, many businesses 
suffer from limited access to commercial credit, and the development of the private sector will benefit from the 
increased availability of appropriately priced financial products, which in turn, will encourage employment creation 
associated with the expected growth of SMEs. 
 
On a more fundamental level, an overall effective financial system can provide services that are equally available to 
the urban and rural population, the financially well-off and the poor.  Expansion of the financial sector, particularly in 
the Lao PDR, is a key requirement for a more equitable distribution of the benefits from rising growth rates and a 
more robust business sector. Efforts to reach out to all regions and facilitate access to credit on commercial terms will 
be critical to narrowing the gap in the Lao PDR. Improving access to financial services will boost widespread 
productivity growth and employment creation. 
 
In the Lao PDR, there are five main channels by which banking system reform can contribute to further poverty 
reduction:

Fiscal space 
Distribution of income and wealth 
Employment creation

The Government’s Reform Program has several major components that aim at the ultimate goal of poverty reduction.  
These include banking sector reform, and the development of an enabling environment and better institutions to 
provide financial services to the rural sector.    
Bank restructuring 
The improved performance of banks will produce economic growth and thus provide a significantly positive impact on 
poverty reduction. Further, given the current lack of investments in areas such as rural infrastructure, education, and 
health, improvement in bank performance frees fiscal resources to provide a much-needed boost in the social portion 
of the budget. Lastly, increased confidence in the banking system and enhanced macrostability can be expected to 
lead, in turn, to a lower risk premium on domestic financial assets (lowering the costs of borrowing), increased 
domestic savings, increased foreign investment, significantly diminished pressures on the Lao currency and a 
reduced risk of a fiscal and monetary crisis.

Impact on access of the poor to finance 
While the poor may not benefit directly from this loan component in the short term, they are likely to receive indirect 
benefits as a result of higher rates of economic growth, which should lead to increased employment.  In the medium 
term, with lower costs of financial services and price levels, the poor’s access to credit and asset accumulation will 
also improve.   
Impact on rural areas 
Along with the inaccessibility to credit to the poor, there is also a significant urban/rural divide.  Because the current 
banking system is inefficient and biased toward urban areas, it creates substantial obstacles for the development of 
rural finance. Reform in the banking system may increase the supply of credit to rural households. The program’s 
objective is, among others, to develop a more diversified and commercial-oriented rural credit system. This should 
help accelerate economic growth and expand employment opportunities and thereby improve the distribution of 
income and wealth in the rural areas.
